Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 06:59PM HollyinMich wrote: Hello Ladies!  I hope that everyone is having a great morning!  I had my first tx yesterday.  My skin already has some sensaion of a bit of a sunburn to it.  No visible redness, just that sensitive feeling that you get at the start of a sunburn and a bit warm to the touch.  I have to admit I was a bit shocked that I felt it so quickly and with my sensitive, fair skin I have a feeling I will be one of those that will have to take a break or two from rads. ReadingMama, I am also on Herceptin every 3 weeks.  Well ladies, speaking of appointments, I need to get ready to meet with the lympedema PT.  My first meeting and while I haven't had a problem with it yet I'm hoping to get ahead of the curve on it and get a sleeve ordered just in case.  I only had 8 nodes out but they are zapping the hell out of my axillary and my subclavian nodes.  I'd rather be prepared and proactive than reactive to it if it should occur!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 09:35PM HollyinMich wrote: My fingers are still swollen, but it seems to be slightly better in the meaty part of my hand where the thumb joins the rest.  I see my med onco at 1:30 before rads to discuss some joint aches I've been having that are either late Taxol SEs or from Herceptin.  The aches come and go but seem to be the worst when the weather shifts like arthritis.  Unfortunately nothing has helped to relieve the pain when they do come and I've tried everything from Vicodin to all the over the counter pain relievers.  But anyway, I will bring up the finger swelling when I see him. ReadingMama - I would ask your rad onco about the LE.  He should be able to refer you to a PT and write you a script for the sleeve and glove or gauntlet.  I was going to go ahead and just take my script in and get fitted today but I figured I'd hold off until after my appointment this afternoon. Gymnut - Of course it's ok if you post here!  Welcome to the thread!  Sorry to hear your rads got off to a rough start but glad to see that things are looking better for you!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2011 02:01AM HollyinMich wrote: Hi ladies!  So sorry I haven't posted in such a long time, life seems to have been super busy lately!  Just had 19/33 today!  I'm very fair skinned and so far my skin has ben holding up beautifully.  Unlike most of you, though, I had a BMX so I don't have to worry about bras or skin breakdown under the breast.  My skin is getting a bit more pink, but no skin sloughing or flakiness.  Some minor itching but it doesn't seem to be a constant thing and if I'm having a day where it's bothering me the lidocain gel they gave me works well.  So far all I've been using is Eucerin lotion in the morning after my shower, Aloe in the afternoon after tx and the Aquaphor at night before bed.  This seems to be working well for me.  I've just started to begin feeling fatigued, but it's still nothing in comparison to the chemo fatigue and so far has been managable.  Wishing all you ladies continued luck for minimal side effects in your treatments!!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 03:24AM HollyinMich wrote: Hi Ladies!  I was supposed to start my rads the first week in April,but they bumped me up so I have my first appointment on Moday!  I have to admit I'm nervous. Blonde hair, blue eyes and extreamly sensitive fair skin.  The nurse already told me to expect a bit more of burn than most.  I also have delayed recon, my oncologist told me to wait at least 2 years before starting.  Hopefully my skin will bounce back a bit with that amount of time to heal.  I've heard recon after rads can be difficult.  I try not to worry to far ahead, but sometimes it's hard, lol.  Wishing everyone the best of luck and hoping all of our SE's are minimal!!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 11:48AM HollyinMich wrote: Crap.....was just getting ready to head to bed and went to throw a load of clothes in the washer/dryer.  I've been trying to make up for the lack of really taking care of the laundry these past several months through chemo and surgery recovery.  Anyhow, it's a bit on the warm side in the house.  Get upstairs with a clean load of laundry in the basket, turn off most of the lights and lock up.  Sit down and I'm feeling a bit warm and kinda sweaty, look down and now my right hand is a bit swollen and the skin in my forearm feels tight.  Gah, I hope a good night's sleep with my arm elevated will do the trick otherwise I'll be off to fill that prescription I've been hanging on to for my LE sleeve.  I see my med onco tomorrow before rads, guess I have something to talk about besides my achey joints. Sagina - Good luck on Thursday!  As far as what to wear, it really doesn't matter much from the waist up.  You change into a gown before tx and just leave everything from the waist down on.  My techs are pretty good about trying to keep everything covered that doesn't need to be exposed for the zaps. AimeeMac - Same here.  15 min drive to the treatment center.  So thankful I don't have a long drive too! Christine - Welcome to the thread!  I noticed the ache too right away.  For me, though, I start feeling it right after my tx, but it's usually gone by the time I head to bed. Goodnight ladies, hoping I have good news about my arm in the morning.
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2011 06:30AM HollyinMich wrote: Sammolisa - Sorry I've been away from the computer for a few days.  I use just the regular Eucerin lotion not the paste.  It's called "Eucerin Original Moisturizing Lotion".  The lotion seems to be a bit thinner than other body lotions and absorbs very quickly and doesn't leave you with the greasy feeling.  I've had no problems using it in the mornings (at least 4 hours prior to rads of course) and it's always absorbed in nicely before rads.  I throw it on after my shower in the morning and then lube up with the Aquaphor after rads and in the evening.  My rads are at 2 pm every day. ReadingMama - Thanks for the heads up on the thread on where to look for the Aloe gel.  I haven't picked any up yet but was wondering what was a good brand, etc. that didn't contain alcohol and where to buy.  Lol, you did the homework for me.  Thanks!! Good luck to all the ladies starting this week and welcome to all the newcomers!!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 03:35AM HollyinMich wrote: Sammolisa - That's awful!  Nothing worse than a tech preaching to you especialy when I'm sure they've never been in that position.  If she happens to do that to you again I'd look at her and say let me see you stretched out on a table in an awkward position for this long and see how still you are!  Gah, some people.  On the bright side, your treatments should be faster now.  The first was definitely the longest.  Now I'm in and out in about 15 minutes except for Mondays (takes an additional 5 min for weekly films) and Thursdays when I see the RO. Picked up some Fruit of the Earth aloe gel this afternoon.  Can't wait to try it.  I was noticing some redness yesterday but it seems to have gone away today.  Number 6 down 27 more to go!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 08:28AM - edited Apr 1, 2011 08:31AM by HollyinMich Doreyme, so far so good.  The initial sensitivity I had has subsided quite a bit.  Day 2 was a bit more sensitive and by the morning of day 3 it had subsided.  Just had number 4 today and I'm not really noticing it much at all.  I guess my skin is adjusting to it.  I'm hoping I keep this trend for as long as I can!  I've been lubing up at night really well with Aquaphor and using Eucerin in the mornings after my shower.  The Eucerin is not greasy like the Aquaphor and absorbs in real well before I go in for Rads.  They told me not use anything 4 hours prior, lol, I'm assuming so that the "grease" doesn't help cook the skin. I haven't noticed too much swelling as of yet.  I had a little bit this morning because idiot me took a really hot bath to help with the body aches I'm getting now almost 2 months out from Taxol.  Uggh, got to love those late SE's.  I didn't think about it and stuck part of my arm in the water for a few minutes before it dawned on me.  So I had a little tightness from a bit of swelling in my upper arm but it's disapated now thank goodness!!
Posts.Title: April 2011 Rads sammolisa sammolisa

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 08:54PM HollyinMich wrote: Faith, thanks so much for the info.  How long were you on one dose before you increased it?  I have axillary numbness as well.  That doesn't bother me so much and it's my understanding that it may never go away.  The sensation I have in the skin is really the issue.  It's quite irritating.  I'm currently on 300 mg 3 times a day.  It does help, but it's still noticeable.
Posts.Title: Nerve Pain post BMX with Axillary Dissection Question HollyinMich dannade

Posts.Content: HollyinMich wrote: I had a BMX with right axillary dissection on February 18, 2011.  While I understand and knew going into the surgery that there would be areas of numbness post surgery I wasn't prepared for the nerve pain that I am now experiencing.  My tricep area in my right arm is the worst.  The skin area isn't quite numb and feels as if I have a sunburn or as is if the skin has been really chaffed that's the best way I can explain it.  It's very painful and uncomfortable when it's touched or rubs against my clothing.  So far I find that it's been detrimental to my ability to really move that arm because of the sensation when anything touches it and I don't want it to interfere with regaining my range of motion back.  The vicodin I've been taking post surgery has not helped with the nerve pain just the sorenes from the surgery itself.  Have any of you ladies experienced something similar to this and if so how did you cope with it?  DH is a nurse and he suggested I ask for a nerve blocker like Lyrica or Gabapentin but I have to admit I'm a bit leary to add any medications that I have to worry about more SE from.    DX w/Brain Mets on 8/30/11. If God only gives you what you can handle then he must think I am Superwoman! Dx 8/12/2010, IBC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/8 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Nerve Pain post BMX with Axillary Dissection Question HollyinMich dannade

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 02:40PM HollyinMich wrote: Well, I went to the doc to get the script for Neurontin.  I've only been taking it for a couple of days now,  I have noticed a decrease in the amount of pain I was having before but it hasn't eliminated it all together.  Is it something that builds up in your system or is this the best it's going to get?  Also, I tried the other day this lidocain cream I had (they gave it to me to use on my port site and I never did) just to see if it would do anything and nope nothing, lol.  I've also added a B12 supplement, hopefully that'll help too but I would imagine that it's take some time to build in my system.

I really don't know where to start looking for a doc who is good with pain management or who can refer me to a PT.  I'm thinking I'll call and set up an appointment with my family doc in the morning and start from there.  He's pretty good and should be able to point me in the right direction I'm hoping!

Posts.Title: Nerve Pain post BMX with Axillary Dissection Question HollyinMich dannade

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 07:45PM HollyinMich wrote: Oh, I used to get so annoyed with the constant "how are you doing" or "how are you feeling".  My mom was the absolute worst for that.  I would tell her, "Mom, I'm the same as I was an hour ago when I talked to you and no I don't know anything more than I did then!"  But, I knew that she and everyone else was just concerned for me.  There were definitely times especially in the first few weeks that I just had to shut my phone off for a bit.  Thankfully, most of our friends were very understanding and waited to hear from us as opposed to bombarding us with calls and such. Enjoy your evening with friends and have a wonderful weekend.  Be sure to keep us posted on what you find out Monday and good luck!  Lots of hugs and prayers!
Posts.Title: Need to Join - Got My Results rjbaby69 rjbaby69

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 08:20PM HollyinMich wrote: I agree with raincitygirl, that seems odd that they would schedule all of that immediately after surgery.  The pain I can imagine won't be horrible, but your still going to be sore as heck!
Posts.Title: Need to Join - Got My Results rjbaby69 rjbaby69

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 05:12PM HollyinMich wrote: I can't compare my situation with yours as I really wasn't given many choices, but I will say this, do what makes you feel the most comfortable.  About the only choice I had was between a single mastectomy or a double.  I opted for the double and initially my oncologist was uncomfortable with my decision but grew to agree with it as time went on. I can imagine that you are confused right now.  Sleep on it and give it some time to sink in.  Then go with what your heart tells you is best.  I am sorry I can't offer more advice than that, but you have to do what you feel is best and not what anyone else thinks is best for you.
Posts.Title: Need to Join - Got My Results rjbaby69 rjbaby69

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 05:50PM HollyinMich wrote: No problem, I hope my story lets you know that thery are still good men out there.  I really am sorry that you are having to deal with all of that.  Like Bonnie said though you have 24 hour support here!  So please feel free to vent all you need! Know that it's very common with something as serious as cancer to undergo life altering views!!  It's amazing how much of a wake up call it can be.  Also, with my daughter I was very open with her about what I was going through.  I explained up front that mommy was going to be feeling pretty badly and that I would need her help.  I was also sure to tell her that sometimes it might make me crabby but to know that no matter what I loved her.  It helped me to try to explain it also in terms that she would understand by using examples of when she wasn't feeling well or tired and crabby.  She has been really wonderful through all of this and hasn't gotten scared about any of it.  It really has helped that I was very open with her.  You'd be surprised how much they understand!
Posts.Title: relationship will not survive timerdog alamik

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 11:11AM HollyinMich wrote: Yes it is "supposed" to be very rare but what I am finding more and more is that I think it was just misdiagnosed for so many years that it got thrown into the rare category.  I don't think it's a rare as they say, I've meet many, many women with this same rare disease. Don't beat yourself up over negligence.  I found that pesky lump a full year and a half before I made it in to the doctor.  I didn't know I had a family history either until a few months ago. My dad died when I was 22 and we were never close with his side of the family so we rarely talked about them.  Turns out bc runs rampant on my paternal grandmothers side of the family.  Oh if I had only known that before!  I thought the worst too because I had let it go for so long.  I also had the IBC symptoms for 3 months before I was able to sort out insurance and get my butt in.  So you are not doomed by any means!!
Posts.Title: Fibrocystic Breasts Lavender250 Springtime

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 10:29AM HollyinMich wrote: Thank you Lavender, yes, I am ok now I guess, I am still here!!! lol Yes, it is very scary and I can relate to all that you are going through.  For me the scariest part was where you are at now; not knowing, playing the waiting game between tests and getting lost in my own thoughts about it!  Once I knew and had a treatment plan in place I calmed down a lot.  You move from the anxious flight or fight mode into the let's get this done fight mode!  Here I am a year later and almost done with treatment (I am Her2+ so I have to be on Herceptin for a year total).  I had a very aggressive cancer so they threw the book at it (chemo, bilateral mastectomy and radiation) and so far it's worked!  So keep in mind that regardless what the outcome is you can do it!
Posts.Title: Fibrocystic Breasts Lavender250 Springtime

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 09:57AM HollyinMich wrote: Lavendar250 - Rushell above posted some very good suggestions.  I understand that you are scared and rightfully so.  I hate to add any additional fears to your concern but the notion that cancer isn't painful is completely incorrect.  I was diagnosed at 17 with fibrocystic breasts.  I had lumps that would come and go all the time and, yes, they were usually painful and appeared with menstrual changes.  When I was 32 I had a lump pop up with a menstrual cycle that was again painful.  I had just been laid off from work and had lost my insurance coverage.  So needless to say I brushed it off as just another fibroid.  It didn't go away unlike all the other fibroids I had in the past.  It was very painful as well.  I finally got it looked at a year later when I was able to obtain insurance and only after I had also developed other rather alarming symptoms (IBC-Inflammatory Breast Cancer).  I made the assumption because of my financial situation at the time and I think out of fear as well before I was diagnosed that it couldn't be cancer because I was too young, I had breastfed and most of all because it hurt.  Boy, was I ever wrong!  My experience dispelled a lot of myths for me.  You can get breast cancer at any age and just because a lump is painful doesn't mean it isn't cancer! You are doing the right thing by having it checked!  Be persistant, don't let doctors blow you off because of your age and if you notice any changes in the lump report them to your doctor immediately!  I wish you all the best of luck and truly hope that it IS nothing.
Posts.Title: Fibrocystic Breasts Lavender250 Springtime

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2011 04:01PM HollyinMich wrote: Fightinhrd123 - Over 5 years with no reoccurrence is awesome and definitely gives me hope! Thank you so much for sharing that! So happy to hear that you also had a complete response too! ProudMom_Wife - Thank you so much for the compliment. That was indeed the purpose of starting this thread. With so many threads dedicated to the SEs of chemo, I thought it would be nice to have one that helps to show the light at the end of the tunnel. Some of the treatments are harder than others and if you are one of the unlucky ones that gets hit hard with the SEs it's nice to know that it pays off in the end! Hillck - So happy to hear that you also had a complete response and that you bounced back so quickly from the chemo! InTwoPlaces - I hope it has for you too!! That was the nice part of having the neoadjuvant treatment was actually being able to see the difference. I certainly have faith that it did do some good for you. I have the same feeling about radiation now. It's hard when you can't physically know for sure that it's doing something other than burning your skin, but I just have to keep the faith and know that I am doing everything possible to help prevent a reoccurrence. Thank you ladies for sharing your stories!!
Posts.Title: How has chemo affected the outcome of your BC? HollyinMich HollyinMich

Posts.Content: HollyinMich wrote: For some chemotherapy may be a choice depending on their diagnosis and for others it is a necessity. The list of side effects can be terrifying. Combine that with a recent cancer diagnosis that already has you terrified and you can become overwhelmed very easily. Everyone's situation is different and therefore the options presented to you are also different. Someone with Stage I may have no need for chemo. Whereas, someone who is Stage II may be advised to undergo chemo but is given more as an option to reduce reoccurrence as opposed to someone with Stage III that is told it is a necessity. With that having been said, I chose to start this thread to shed a positive light on the good chemotherapy can do. I'd like to see all the ladies that have completed chemotherapy share their stories as to how it has impacted their outcome in this fight for our lives. I hope that if these stories are compiled in one thread it will help someone in their own journey and decision making process and eliminate the need to wade through all of the numerous threads on this site, which can be a daunting task all on its own especially when newly diagnosed.  I apologize in advance if this has been done before, but I have not seen a thread like this and thought it could be useful. This thread is NOT the place to chastise anyone's choice to undergo chemo, but rather share our stories. If you can't be nice then feel free to voice your opinions elsewhere. My own personal story to follow. DX w/Brain Mets on 8/30/11. If God only gives you what you can handle then he must think I am Superwoman! Dx 8/12/2010, IBC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/8 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How has chemo affected the outcome of your BC? HollyinMich HollyinMich

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 02:57PM - edited Mar 12, 2011 03:03PM by HollyinMich Holy crap!  I am soooo sooo sorry that you are having to deal with that on top of cancer!  As if cancer wasn't bad enough!  I was also a single mom with an 8 year old.  My boyfriend (now my husband) had been living together for a couple of year before I got sick.  I had no insurance and was laid off of work when my symptoms developed.  My DH is a nurse, I helped him through nursing school.  He was against marriage (as was I) but married me so I could get health insurance to get better and have the peace of mind that if something did happen to me, my daughter would be fine.  Her biological father passed away three years ago.  He has taken on the burden of supporting me and my daughter financially and emotionally through all of this.  As opposed as he was to marriage, he doesn't regret his decision one bit and has never looked back!  After having experienced this kind of selflessness and love I truly consider myself lucky! Your boyfriend sounds like a selfish a$$!  And after having the great experience of being lucky enough to find a TRUE man it makes me so mad for you!  I hope things start looking up for you soon!  I know how hard it is to try and remain strong.  I hope you have family close by that you can lean on for help.  Research the internet for organizations that might be able to help you financially and talk to the Social Worker at your hospital  They can refer you and help you find the financial help that you need. Also, keep in mind that while chemo does suck it's not as bad as it used to be and it's certainly not as bad as Hollywood like to make it out.  We all experience it differently so no one can say for sure that you won't have this side effect or that you will have another.  I know it's scary, but it is doable!  And your oncologist will help you to manage your side effects so make sure you talk to him/her about any that you experience.  The oncology nurses are always a great resource too.  They have seen it all and they will be able to offer you a lot of support.

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2011 09:37PM HollyinMich wrote: I was diagnosed at age 33 with IDC and Inflammatory Breast Cancer (IBC) in August of 2010. Having IBC automatically makes me a Stage IIIb. My biopsy showed angiolymphatic invasion, grade 3 tumor, HER2 positive ER/PR negative. I had axillary lymph node involvement that was palpable and visible in mammogram, CT and PET scans. No sentinel node biopsy was performed because the scans were all positive for involvement. I immediately began dose dense A/C the day after I met with my oncologist and had discussed my biopsy pathology reports with him. I had 4 rounds of DD A/C that I received every two weeks followed by 12 weeks of weekly Taxol and Herceptin that I finished on January 19, 2011. I am now currently on Herceptin every three week through January of 2012. Since I began chemotherapy as neoadjuvant (prior to surgery) I was able to visibly see and feel the difference the chemo was making. After the very first infusion my very swollen and red breast began to reduce in size and the redness began to turn brownish kind of like tanned skin. After tx #2 the redness was completely gone and the swelling gone as well. I had two IDC tumors in my breast. The smaller second tumor I completely lost track of during A/C. The large 4.8 cm primary tumor shrunk steadily and consistently throughout treatment. I had a bilateral mastectomy on February 18, 2011. Left prophylactic mx and right mrm with right axillary node dissection that resulted in 8 nodes removed. Post surgical pathology reports showed a COMPLETE RESPONSE to chemotherapy. No residual cancer cells remained in the primary tumor site, the secondary tumor was completely gone and no residual cancer cells in the axillary lymph nodes. My oncologist was bursting at the seams with the good news. I am currently undergoing radiation therapy. Even with the complete response to chemo, IBC has an extremely high rate of reoccurrence coupled with additional rate of reoccurrence due to my Her2 status. Radiation further reduces my risk of reoccurrence by 50%. The five months of chemotherapy were hell on my body but well worth the outcome. Having one of the most aggressive and deadly forms of breast cancer, chemo has given me the hope that I'll still be here to see my 8 year old daughter become a young woman, go on her first date, learn to drive, graduate high school, go to college and hopefully I'll still be here to see her get married and start a family of her own! I don't regret one minute of my chemo.
Posts.Title: How has chemo affected the outcome of your BC? HollyinMich HollyinMich

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 02:58PM HollyinMich wrote: Oh my, you ladies all give me hope!  My hair has been frustrating me to no end!  I'm about 6 weeks PFC but my hair started coming back in (the white peach fuzz) about a month before my last weekly Taxol.  It has been so patchy and reminiscent of male pattern baldness that I've been telling DH that I look like a little old man and especially so now that I'm post BMX.  It's encouraging to hear and see that the hair will fill in!  I've been so anxious about this.  I know that it's probably silly considering I have so many other things to worry about, but prior to BC I always loved my hair!  Thanks ladies for posting your photos and your hair journey stories!!

Geo, I've heard that delayed recon is easier.  I'm in the same boat, but my recon I've been told has to be two years out because I have IBC not just due to radiation.  I have to admit I feel for the ladies who are getting hit with the double whammy of surgery and recon at the same time!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 12:48PM HollyinMich wrote: Skyydiamond, yes the nerve pain in the arm is from the node removal for sure.  I actually just went to my family doc today to try a prescription for Neurontin to see if that helps.  It's really been driving me crazy.  My poor DH almost got decked today when he, lovingly mind you, touched that part of my arm!  Lol, he had forgotten about it and went to rub my arm as part of a gesture and I instantly yelled at him to stop touching me.  I felt bad afterwards, but goes to show how sensitive it is! Slinky, oh my, I would have blown a gasket!  I'm the type that has a hard time biting my tounge about stuff like that.  Knowing me I would have asked for the charge nurse and complained immeditely! I also had a relatively good hospital experience.  My nurses were awesome.  The only complaint I had was having to share the room with someone who was not very quite at all.  She moaned in pain constantly for attention and was very combative with the nurses.  Ugh, was very annoying.  After hearing a list of her meds though, I realized she had some mental health problems as well, so I did my best just to deal with it.  Thankfully I was only there one night and I knew I'd be home soon!

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 01:38AM HollyinMich wrote: I'm sooo happy that it passed in MI for medical use, unfortunately, I haven't seen or heard of any dispensiaries yet.  I've always been for it's legalization for the same reasons that many have already posted.  Thankfully, I have a mother who has been a 40+ year smoker of it.  If it weren't for her my DD round of A/C would have been intolerable.  It was the only thing that really helped with my nausea.  Zofran made me feel worse and Compazine didn't do a thing for it.  I haven't needed it since, but I still have a little leftover stash on hand in case I do!

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 03:33PM HollyinMich wrote: Hello Ladies, Just wanted to pop in and wish everyone good luck for their surgeries this week.  I had my BMX with right axillary dissection on the 18th.  So far I've ben feeling really well.  My right side is a bit more sore than the left, but other than that I really have no complaints with how I feel.  I actually think the tape from the dressings has been more of an annoyance than anything else.  I see my onco in the morning to get the patho results and to start planning out the next step of treatment.  I'm a bit concerned though the surgeon didn't remove enough skin tissue on the IBC affected breast, so I will have to discuss that with my onco tomorrow as well.  I hope all the ladies who have already undergone surgery this month are recovering well!  You are all in my thoughts and prayers!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2011 10:30AM HollyinMich wrote: Rennasus, so glad to hear that you are doing so well!  Cameron, thanks!  Went to see the surgeon today and thank god he removed the drains!  They were driving me crazy!  He ran a suture through my skin about a half an inch below the drain insertion and tied it to the drain to secure it.  I am soooo sore from the suture constantly pulling on my skin!  Lol, I swear if he hadn't taken them out I think I would have.  I requested a copy of the pathology results while I was there too.  When I saw my oncologist last week he only had verbal results from the pathologist as they were not in the computer yet.  I was very pleasantly surprised that the main tumor in my breast also showed no remaining cancer cells and a secondary tumor I had at diagnosis had completely disappeared!!  My oncologist was so focuses on the lymph node results that were also clear and so excited about it I had forgotten to ask about the breast tissue itself, lol!  So, yay, for chemo!!!  Of course, my oncologist is still being cautious and I still have to undergo rads because I also presented with IBC in addition to the tumors and I had a Nottingham score of 8 (9 being the worst) so I have to worry about a high rate of reoccurance, but this news has made me very hopeful!!  I also have my fingers crossed that maybe with all this good news he might give me the ok to begin reconstruction sooner than the initial 2 years he told me I would have to wait.  I'm still in a good deal of pain and dealing with the nerve damage from the axillay dissection, but the good news has certainly helped to make it a bit more tolerable!  Sending good wishes to everyone and hope you all are recovering well!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 04:04AM - edited Jan 30, 2011 04:11AM by HollyinMich Scheduled for a bilateral mastectomy on Feb 18th with non-skin sparing on the right, right axillary dissection and simple on the left.  No immediate reconstruction plans.  Doc says I have to wait at least 2 years for reconstruction due to the reoccurance rate of IBC. My mom will be staying with my family for a couple of weeks following surgery to help out and make sure her baby is ok, lol. :-)  I'm certainly not going to argue against the help! I think I am feeling more anxious over the upcoming MRI and PET scan than I am about the surgery itself because those will tell the real story as to how well I have responded to chemo. I just did a whole house clean too in order to prepare for all the family that I know will be coming by, lol.  As far as post surgical wear, Suefly, check out TLCdirect.  The have a nice camisole and a drain belt that looks handy.  I am debating on ordering them both for myself.  DH is a nurse and he says I should be fine without them but they look like the would offer a bit of help with keeping the drains managed.  He says I can just pin them to my shirt, but you know how men are!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 12:11AM HollyinMich wrote: Suefly, I live in Michigan and we had the same thing.  Started to feel like Spring and thrust right back into Winter again!  Makes you want to just lay around curled up in a blanket with or without fatigue, lol!  I am still feeling fatigued as well though some days.  Some days are better than others, but I have to admit it's hard to tell sometimes if it's surgery related or insomnia related.  I'm still having trouble sleeping at night.  I still have soreness and it gets hard to fall asleep somtimes at night and the cold snap certainly didn't help matters.
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2011 06:59AM HollyinMich wrote: A small amount of baby oil!  Let it sit for a min and then the residue should come right off without having to scrub.  I had similar tape issues, hope that helps for you and best wishes for a speedy recovery!
Posts.Title: Tape Residue kmpod kmpod

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 06:35PM HollyinMich wrote: MaxineO, some more great ideas!  I also have begun buying some pajamas that have tops that button.  I am more of a t-shirt sweatpants kinda gal and I know that it's going to be difficult for awhile to try and rase my arms getting the t-shirts on and off.  I also saw a post on one of the other boards about using a wedge pillow to make it easier to get up and out of bed after surgery.  I think I'm going to go ahead and order the drain belt I saw on TLC direct since it can be worn with everything.  The cami looks nice but for the price I know I could only afford one and the belt seems more versatile and useful. As far as bathing goes, lol, I've thought about that issue as well and still haven't come up with a good resolution.  I'm hoping that I can find a cheap handheld shower that will attach to the faucet so that we don't have to do a complete showerhead replacement.  Thankfully, I still don't have much hair yet since I just finished chemo.  The peachfuzz is still easily taken care of with a wash cloth.  XD

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 10:32AM HollyinMich wrote: Texasrose - Happy to hear you are doing well after surgery! MaxineO - No, I didn't have any problems getting the anti-anxiety meds.  If your doc gives you any problems with it, well then, he's not a very sympathetic and understanding doc!  It kind of goes without question that you'll be experiencing bouts of anxiety.  Don't be afraid to ask for them, you have every right to have your anxiety treated just as you do with pain management.  That's the nice thing about DH being a nurse is that he's taught me to not be afraid to ask for the meds I need from the doctor to make me feel the best that I can feel.  It's your right as a paitent!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 12:21PM HollyinMich wrote: Windlass, it's not uncommon after having node dissection to still have pain.  I'm almost 3 weeks post op from a BMX with right ALND with no recon and I'm still very sore and experiencing nerve pain in my right arm.  I also experience the burning sensation in my chest that you described.  I'm still taking vicodin for pain and plan on also asking for gabapentin (neurontin) for the nerve pain issues.  Hope you start feeling better soon!

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 06:18PM HollyinMich wrote: Hi Ladies, glad to see that everyone seems to be doing well for the most part.  I'm almost 2 weeks out from my BMX with right axillary dissection.  My oncologist gave me my patho results last week and all the nodes removed came back clear!!  I'm happy about that but at the same time now wishing I hadn't had them removed.  Ahhh, better to be safe than sorry I guess.  Going to see the surgeon tomorrow and hopefully have both drains removed.  He did an odd stich to secure the drains and it's been causing A LOT of discomfort, so I'm really hoping they'll come out tomorrow.  Still on pain meds though, which has kinda bummed me out a bit.  I was hoping by this point to be in a lot less pain than I am, but I guess with the axillary dissection it's to be expected.  Sending all of you ladies hugs and well wishes!!
Posts.Title: February 2011 Mastectomy texasrose361 TinaT

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2011 03:10AM HollyinMich wrote: I had weekly Taxol in combination with Herceptin x 12 and I am now on Herceptin alone every 3 weeks.  For me the side effects from the Taxol and the Herceptin were so much more minimal than the dd A/C.  The Taxol did irritate my sinuses a bit and did cause some noticeable blood when I would blow my nose, but nothing too horrible.  I did have some mild neuropathy in my hands and feet that disappeared completely a few months after treatment.  My finger nails lifted a bit toward the end as well as my toe nails.  I ended up loosing both of my big toe nails after treatment as I had new nail growth that pushed them off.  It really wasn't bad though.  I've read that a lot of women put their hands in ice water and use bags of ice on their feet to help prevent nail loss and to lessen the neuropathy.  I didn't find out about that trick until I was done, but it really wasn't to much of an issue for me. I did have a decrease in the ejection fraction rate of my heart but I'm not entirely sure it was the Herceptin.  It could have been from the A/C.  It has come back up on it's own and I'm still on Herceptin so that leads me to believe it could have been from the dd A/C.  Other that I have some achey joints, but I think that has more to do with the overall lasting effects from chemo, not any one particular treatment in general. The worst side effects for me on the Taxol/Herceptin came from the pre-meds.  They gave me infusions of Benedryl and Decadron prior to Taxol to reduce the risk of an allergic reaction.  The Benedryl would give me a wicked case of restless legs and itchy crawly skin for a couple hours.  I was one of the lucky few who had this reaction, it's not common.  The Decadron is a corticosteroid.  It caused me to have a lot of insomnia, which by the end had worn on me pretty badly.  Again, though, not everyone experiences the effects I had to the degree I did.  You can ask after the first couple of infusions (once the know you're not going to have an allergic reaction) for them to lower the dose a bit if it's causing you problems.  It helps sometimes too if they lower the infusion rate and do it a bit slower for the premeds. Hopefully that answers some of your questions.  Good luck and hoping that you breeze through it!!
Posts.Title: Can anyone list Taxol and Herceptin Side effects? Southamptonmom Southamptonmom

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 07:22PM - edited Mar 8, 2011 07:23PM by HollyinMich Mary, no problem!  If there were no outward signs of skin involvement then you might have caught it before the symptoms appeared, which is a good thing.  IBC by definition is cancer in the dermal lymphatics of the breast.  It's also treated very aggresively since it's an aggresive form of BC.  So if there is any possibility that it may indeed be IBC I would push for an answer on it.  Here's to hoping that it's not, because the chemo treatment sucks!  If it is, have hope.  My chemo regimen prior to my BMX wiped out all the cancer cells; all of my post-op patho results came back clear.  So, even though it sucked going through it, it was well worth it!  Wishing you all the best!!
Posts.Title: anybody else stage 111 because of skin penetration? ctm1 mammalou

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 03:34PM HollyinMich wrote: Hi Mary, sorry to hear that you've joined the ranks of a stage III diagnosis.  I have a very similar diagnosis and mine translates into Inflammatory Breast Cancer hence the stage IIIb diagnosis.  However, at the time of my dx not only did I have two tumors present I also had the physical characteristics of IBC, i.e. swollen red breast with nipple inversion that was hot to the touch and orange peel appearance to the skin.  So basically they knew right off the bat that we were dealing with a stage IIIb cancer.  I would talk to your oncologist about the possibility of IBC, the dermal lymph involvement lends me to believe that it might be a possibility and all IBC dx start off at a stage IIIb.
Posts.Title: anybody else stage 111 because of skin penetration? ctm1 mammalou

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 12:14AM HollyinMich wrote: So sorry to hear that you have a bc diagnosis.  It is a whirlwind in the begining, so much information to digest and understand.  Sue made some very wonderful points above.  Make sure to get copies of all of your reports.  It's so helpful to have them to decipher what your doctors have told you after you leave.  It gives you something to look at later after your appointment to help you digest what they were telling you.  Having someone with you is also a big help.  My husband went with me to all of my initial appointments and it was such a blessing.  He thought of asking for an anti-anxiety med and it had never even crossed my mind.  So glad that he did. The xanax really came in handy for the tests like the MRI and PET to help relax me for them and to just cope in the begining. Best of wishes to you, Maggie and sending lots of prayers your way!
